The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from understanding global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Text: Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports that many people listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help them get out of bed. This is why clock radios are popular. But how do you choose a good one? A panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

The 'dual alarm function' advertised with one model does not let you wake up with the buzzer, snooze, and then get up later, as I first thought. The instruction booklet suggests using this function to set two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. However, who really plans their life this way? This model costs about the same as another we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a nice feature. You can fall asleep to your favorite tapes and wake up without news. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size was an issue—it was as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that any clock radio he buys must leave enough space on the bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was voted the best in terms of appearance and overall performance. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it,' even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I found the digital display interesting, with its stylish grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze button allows you to tap it without opening your eyes. Unfortunately, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which led to confusion when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don’t have to reset it if someone unplugs it to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner; everyone liked this feature. However, we all found it difficult to set up, though mastering it made us feel 'cool' and sophisticated.

Tom Granger described another model, which has a built-in lamp, as 'unbelievably tacky.' He had to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, raising concerns about its quality. He read the instruction booklet twice because the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was hard to position; it only lit up the clock, which was already illuminated. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed that the radio was difficult to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, with its bright colors and matching strap, it appealed to the child in Tom Granger and me. Tom said, 'I would choose this one because it stands out more than the others.' The traditional controls made it the only model we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual states, 'the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time.' Paul Bridges laughed at this idea, saying the model was 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it 'seemed very standard and took up little space,' and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, 'It's easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed all the buttons correctly, so you can’t be confident it will work.' He acknowledged that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to carry less weight, so they have fewer spines and are more likely to run away from danger, using their ability to roll up as a last option. Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during most of the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; in good conditions, some will stay awake all year.

**Text: Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's an amazing feeling to soar through the air and land safely, but it can be frightening. Sometimes I feel unwell or the weather is bad, making it hard to see, but I push through. Having a career outside of skiing is tough because we train for ten months each year. I have to give up much of my social life and time with friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally—it's a young sport."

B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and surprisingly won because I cycled faster than everyone else, even though I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day on the bike, plus I do stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment needed."

C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because very few schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to a lack of stability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy it and love staying fit, plus there is a good social aspect."

D. **Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it is! I found Britain too small and safe. I was very determined and disliked anyone controlling me. Now, I am more diplomatic. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the most painful experience I've had, covering 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to, as my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, making them hesitant to sponsor us."

E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, which you can see on the roads. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I approach a corner, men think, 'I must beat her,' so I've faced many tough moments! You need to be competitive and assertive. It's hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It's encouraging that more women are joining the sport each year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing comes from striving for perfection and aiming for the perfect lap."

F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before races, and during competitions, I really push myself—if I don’t, I feel bad. I’ve often wondered why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t force myself to do this, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also lower for women. However, we have now established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**Simplified Text:**

The day I met Picasso, Richard Cork remembers how, as a 78-year-old student, he encountered one of the most famous artists of the century. Even from a distance, eating lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes, Picasso was easy to recognize. I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old, unreliable van. After running out of money, I found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have a large sketchbook with me when I met the elderly artist.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually worked alone in the hills. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have approached him to ask for his signature. I was nervous as I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below. Picasso's art, even when abstract, often related to real things. So, the lines he drew might represent a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbour.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was worse than my French, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him the Maestro, which made it hard for me to speak. But I managed to tell Picasso about my strong interest in art and my admiration for his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that Picasso's lunch was still going on. "Is that all?" he asked, looking at the signature. "Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this chance? He probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was best not to ask if I could draw him, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, set my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and began to draw. When he noticed, Picasso smiled playfully and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny expressions, rolling his eyes and sticking out his tongue. His playful behavior felt like a challenge, and I didn’t want to give up. Despite his antics, I felt he was testing my determination.

Eventually, Picasso relaxed and allowed me to study him without distractions. I saw how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed more like a fit 60-year-old than a man about to turn 84. His dark eyes were youthful and intense, and I tried to capture that in my drawing. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed distant and alone, quietly focused on his own thoughts.

When the American lady told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. However, Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketchbook, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a bearded face that was very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. After talking with the American, she explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Still, I look back now and feel very lucky. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a lot to me.

**Text: Shopping Strategies**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? Here, we explain the techniques that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

A. **Freshness Appeal**  
Supermarkets understand that customers value fresh food. They often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance or display house plants to create a fresh atmosphere. In-store bakeries fill the air with the smell of fresh bread, making the store more inviting. The colors used in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind shoppers of fresh produce. However, most items sold, like frozen foods and cleaning products, do not match this fresh image.

B. **Product Placement**  
The arrangement of products in a store is crucial for sales. Supermarkets use technology to find out which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these spots, while also using eye-level shelves to catch attention. Special offer bins attract bargain hunters, and complementary items are placed near each other to encourage additional purchases.

C. **Strategic Layout**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to walk past more expensive items, increasing the chance of impulse buys. Stores also position popular products away from the entrance, betting that loyal customers will search for them, thus encountering other tempting items along the way.

D. **Minimalist Display**  
Chain stores have changed how they display products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from cluttered displays to a more stylish presentation, making their clothing seem exclusive. Their success comes from both good design and appealing clothing.

E. **Total Cost Awareness**  
Shoppers tend to focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items, so not everything is cheap. They may sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as "loss leaders." They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in bulk or promoting certain products.

F. **Pricing Strategies**  
In chain stores, customers often buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can influence buying decisions. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

G. **Lighting Effects**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for natural light to show the true colors of clothing, while supermarkets use special lighting to highlight fresh foods.

H. **Store Navigation**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, called the "Yellow Brick Road," help direct customers to sales areas. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use attractive flooring to encourage shoppers to explore.

I. **In-Store Advertising**  
As you enter a supermarket, large colorful images of delicious food catch your eye, especially if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display ads while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and claim to increase sales significantly.

**Text: Sea, Ice & Rock**

Mountaineer Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for reaching the summit of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book: *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

After a while, we reached a steep drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how. When I finished, Robin politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit worried, but he managed to lower himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion that we combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure. 

I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always consulted the crew first. Most of the time, no one dared to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing challenging and quite boring. The moments of crisis were easy to handle because of the adrenaline, but spending days in the middle of the sea was hard for me. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless. 

The crew was also cramped: six people on a 32-foot yacht meant for four. At least on a mountain expedition, you can get some space from each other. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times when, if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be careful about that. I underestimated how difficult the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether we could get it through the ice and if it was still intact. Yet he was eager for us to try climbing the mountain again. 

The only time our relationship almost faced a crisis was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to keep watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I expressed that. Robin quickly reassured me that I had misunderstood his intentions. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we truly got to know each other by the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, existing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, known in Ancient Britain as "windings." They were very different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge included cider-making and was brought to Britain. One dessert apple, called Decio, was likely introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and Norman varieties quickly became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple types, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
During the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term "costermonger," meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This trend continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them precious. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, known as "Johnny Appleseed." Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious beliefs led to many folktales about him, including stories of his kindness to animals.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa discovered a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named the apple "Hawkey." After showing it at a fruit exhibition, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was marketed as "Delicious" and became one of the most widely grown apples globally.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith, the daughter of convicts. She was independent and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as "Granny Smith," she took care of her family's farm and orchard. In 1868, she discovered a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she said, "Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from northern India to Africa. However, most apples come from only a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, rather than for their taste. This lack of variety is harming our enjoyment of apples and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple types, the US has lost most of its apple varieties from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are beginning to seek more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity; we must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Text: Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique destinations and original itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people and are led by experienced guides. This allows you to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local cultures. It’s a rewarding experience for all travelers.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport, often on the same trip. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people who are ready for new experiences. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most participants are between 25 and 55 years old, with many being couples and others traveling solo.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique, so we categorize our adventures into 8 groups based on main activities and interests. Each category highlights special aspects of a tour, but many factors contribute to the overall success of our trips, such as unique places, cultural encounters, and personal involvement.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural focus, with some tours emphasizing local cultures and historical sites. Destinations of cultural interest include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Turkey, Greece, India, and more. Short walks of 2-4 hours to visit lesser-known sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks, allowing thrilling encounters with animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might even step outside your vehicle to explore the wild. Activities can include tracking gorillas in Zaire, hiking with tribal guides in Uganda, or canoeing on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel accommodations.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara or the Maya of Mexico. Many of these cultures face challenges from outside influences. We travel in small groups to promote understanding and respect for different cultures while minimizing environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walking through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. You might hike from village to village, staying in local homes or simple huts. Destinations include Spain, Greece, Morocco, and more. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer a few challenging treks for experienced hikers, sometimes at high elevations. You may stay with local people or camp in stunning mountain ranges like the Himalayas or the Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you won’t need to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an unforgettable adventure. These places, like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert, offer unique experiences for adventurous travelers.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats. You can sail through Upper Egypt, explore the islands of Greece and Thailand, or cruise the Galapagos Islands on a small yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

Our river journeys can last from a few hours to several days, ranging from easy paddling to exciting whitewater rafting. No prior experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of beautiful landscapes and wildlife.

Text: 'Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner from Britain, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain path leads off a quiet road from Nairobi. This path begins the journey up Mount Kenya, the country’s highest peak. This beautiful but isolated place is called Nanyuki. For the past three years, it has been my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners before. On my fourth winter training trip to Kenya, I decided to change that. I participated in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss. Training at high altitude increases the number of red blood cells, which helps carry oxygen better. This has been proven by the success of many Kenyan runners. My first race in Africa was also significant; it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent, in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, and all but three were Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I believe Kenyan success is not only due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple and effective approach to running. Their running style looks effortless, their diet is straightforward, and they enjoy competing. However, the most important question is: how do they train? My time at the training camp gave me the answers. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mt Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. It is quite basic, with few comforts. The athletes live with regular students and share rooms in dormitories. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The day starts at six. We would wake up and gather for a briefing from the coaches before the morning run. "Run easy, you have a hard day ahead," the coach would say. Each day, we covered about 40 kilometers, which is just under a marathon distance. The only exception was Sunday, when we only ran 20 kilometers, a welcome break from the usual three workouts. Outside of running, life was simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth was enough for morning preparations. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs, eaten in a small, dimly lit dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to bathe in one of the streams from Mt Kenya's melting glaciers. By the end of my stay, I had a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the hard training, and the passion for success might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.'

**Text: The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This issue is not just because of the recession; advertising began to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large markets and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen brands a year. If you buy a new car, it is likely provided by your employer, and if not, you may only buy one every three years. You probably do not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you consider all the other products and services, it is very likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In comparison, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are individually listed and analyzed. The average consumer buys about 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are due to advertising. This means that only about 4 percent of advertising is effective. 

When you watch TV tonight, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. Most people find that only about one in 16 commercials (6 percent) are relevant to them, meaning that the other 15 (94 percent) are likely wasted. You might think you are different and not influenced by advertising, but most people feel the same way. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. 

There is always some waste in advertising because not every person who sees an ad will rush out to buy the product. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many advertisements have shown that it can work. Advertisers need to reach a large audience to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested. 

Even with careful targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail campaigns do not achieve a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between media advertising and personal selling. A salesperson might succeed with every potential client they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all; they could contact those individuals directly.

Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers (about 2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For popular soap brands, gaining a million extra customers would be a great success. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can attract more than 2 percent of the population would be considered very successful, and this is just a small part of the population. While mass media can be a cost-effective way to reach people, if advertising is to improve, its messages will need to be more focused than ever before.

**Text: 'Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Greenest Home'**

Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting features. First, it is home to Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral that is not well-known. Writers who care about the environment appreciate the pagan 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in the cathedral's thirteenth-century chapter house. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale, which is considered the greenest home in Britain.

The Vales have created a home that uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into compost for the garden, and heats the house using waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the burnt-orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and received approval from planners, even in a conservation area.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice complete silence. The house is very well-insulated, with triple-glazed windows filled with krypton gas, which keeps outside noise out. Inside, after removing your shoes as Robert requests, you will find a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow, as the house is designed to be draught-proof, even having a small air-locked door for the cats.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to eliminate the need for mains water as well. They designed composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water safe, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe using strong detergents is wrong.

Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much less harmful to the environment without living in darkness." The only medieval feature of the house is its design: the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, extends to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p, which is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.

Soon, they will install £20,000 worth of solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden, which will allow the house to generate more electricity than it uses. They will still need to draw some electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances, but they expect to have enough surplus electricity to eventually charge an electric car. The only source of heat in the house is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they claim to use only during the coldest winter days.

When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he found it comfortable because there were no draughts and everything felt the same temperature. He noted that a woman from the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggests that people living in homes built before 1900 should adapt to that lifestyle again, though this idea may not be popular.

The secret to the house's success is its simplicity and low-tech design, which means there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were sourced from local builders and installed by local craftsmen, making the house affordable to build—costing the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are resistant to this approach.

Text: 'The Camera Never Lies

Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of Sherlock Holmes, thought of himself as a rational man and even a scientist. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published the photos with an article, accepting fairies as magical beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a basic idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and always has been able to. Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Text: Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths held a status similar to that of doctors and astrologers because they were the only ones who made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also crafted by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased, as heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used graceful wrought-iron features.

In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more open approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced seems clichéd, with manufacturers of gates and balconies promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can hardly enter a trendy design store without seeing rusty candlesticks with unnecessary decorations. Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmithing craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, states, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently."

Power tools have freed blacksmiths from the hard work of using a hot anvil, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld metal more easily. "In short," says Dawson, "these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork, according to Dawson. His own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a hand-blown glass shade. "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space," he explains.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, says, "It's quite magical because it's very soft when hot, but as soon as it cools, it becomes hard and unmovable again." Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles that seem inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, while another resembles a Celtic cross. "I love that steel is cold and hard," she says. "It feels like it will last forever." No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are high, as long as we don't have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING'**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying. I still find it strange. The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I had not planned to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won't be trying to stop myself; that wouldn't be fair." I thought it was reasonable because I enjoyed smoking. It gave me real pleasure. The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. 

What happened was that the messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge because of opposition, the idea of quitting started to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling. Could I also achieve other things? In many ways, it was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. The one thing I thought would be hard to do without cigarettes was my work, but it turned out to be fine. I had believed I wouldn't be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing simple things at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I am starting to think that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

Text: 'Dorothy who? The only British woman scientist to win the Nobel Prize should be well-known in her own country, says Georgina Ferry, but she is not. For the past four years, I have been testing friends and acquaintances on their knowledge of Dorothy Hodgkin. It’s simple: when I tell them I am writing her biography, if they respond with excitement and say things like, "Surely there's one already!" they pass the test. Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? The fact that she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize should be enough. Anyone with the same achievement in literature would be famous. But Hodgkin, who died in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes of the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science. 

When I started my research, I wanted to read some scientific biographies. One of Hodgkin's friends suggested a new biography of Linus Pauling. Pauling was a close friend of Hodgkin, worked in the same field, and campaigned against nuclear weapons. I rushed to the main bookstore in my university town, only to find that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I now realize I was naive to think Pauling would be interesting to British readers, even though he was a highly influential chemist of the 20th century and won Nobel Prizes in both chemistry and peace. Even scientists have questioned the value of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull to read. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. 

Treating scientists differently from others in biographies shows the 'two cultures' mentality, the idea that there is a big gap between the arts and sciences, which still exists in the literary world. Only a few great scientists make it into the biography sections of bookstores. It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, actors, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. A leading geneticist once told me he was happy to discuss his work but did not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem 'self-promoting'. This avoidance of personal stories gives a false impression of science and may discourage young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, things are changing. Contemporary scientists now often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars on television. These activities may raise eyebrows in laboratories, but they help make scientists more relatable than many academic papers do. The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies and autobiographies used to be very serious and dull. The personal lives of scientists—like marriage and children—were often briefly mentioned. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?, which is a funny and touching memoir of a man who was also one of the greatest theoretical physicists of the century. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws. 

To readers, it does not matter that Einstein's family life is 'irrelevant' to his General Theory of Relativity. The way creative geniuses deal with emotional ups and downs and everyday life is interesting in itself. Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. Her major achievements included solving the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She pushed scientific techniques to new levels of complexity. However, she also had three children and a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. Her personal life may not be directly related to her work as a scientist, but we can learn from how she balanced different parts of her life. 

There is much in her life that is universally interesting, but it would be unfair to suggest that this does not include her scientific work. Scientific inquiry was the passion of Hodgkin's life, as it must be for any successful scientist. Communicating this passion is the biggest challenge for a scientific biographer. Most readers do not have enough basic scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without a lot of explanation. Understanding scientific concepts is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a foreign language—it just requires effort. It is unfortunate that educated people, who would feel embarrassed if they did not recognize a famous literary or artistic figure, remain unaware of the rich legacy represented by scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.'

**Text: Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for her special ability to find water. She can use a forked hazel stick to locate underground water sources. Many farmers whose wells have dried up are seeking her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she relies only on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water, known as dowsing, is often described as a "sixth sense." There are various theories about how dowsing works, including ideas related to magnetism and spirituality. One popular theory suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can sense these vibrations, while others claim they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to drought, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns that have become holiday homes, where installing long water pipes is too costly. There are also golf course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret typically looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She emphasizes the importance of avoiding areas where waste could contaminate the water supply. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and if they bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, where they work, there are many minerals, so they must be careful about iron in the water.

Electricity is also needed to run the pump, and it is expensive to bring power over long distances, so it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. Once she considers these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map; it swings when she is above a water source.

After identifying possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also dowse the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill until they reach a consensus. Margaret is not alone in her practice; many anthropologists and writers have been intrigued by this mysterious skill. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard to understand how her family could continue to thrive in their well-drilling business year after year.

**Simplified Text: 'We Changed Lives for a Day!'**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be fun to try something new! We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**A. Amanda's Story**

I had never been to a place like this before. It was dark and loud, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and honestly, I wasn't sure I could handle it! Being a mother is busy, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. I felt so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!

By opening time at 11:30 am, there was already a line outside, and I started to feel nervous. I worried about remembering all the orders, but luckily, everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn’t get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was completely tired and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn’t believe it when one of the waitresses said it had been a 'quiet' day! I never realized how tiring waitressing could be. I always thought it was an easy job, but you really need to be friendly and able to handle a lot of customers at once. I’m quite shy, and I don’t think I could manage on a busy Saturday night. I wasn’t impressed with the pay either. Sadly, I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very happy to return to my children. It felt easy compared to waitressing!

**B. Cindy's Story**

I was a bit nervous about being a 'mum' for a day, but I was also excited. I had been told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could manage. As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, rushed through the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble began. They turned the couch into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming loudly! I thought they would tire out soon, but I was wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they wore me out! After much effort, I got them to bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun began! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I realized they were just trying to come downstairs to watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never knew how tiring it could be to take care of two small children. You don’t have a moment to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's Story**

On the farm, I wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a treat! I took a long time deciding how to dress. I couldn’t show up in my farm clothes, could I? Looking at about 400 students at assembly, I hoped I blended in and that my fresh face didn’t make me stand out as a farmer. After that, I went to a math class. The children worked in small groups with different levels of difficulty - very different from my school days when we recited tables together! Then I helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There’s so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (which was nice!) and then a French lesson in the video room. This was fun because all the children wanted to practice on me, which showed how rusty my French was. Finally, we went to the gym for Physical Education. I was exhausted, but the children had endless energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class - even for just two minutes, it was scary. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I’ll stick to farming!

**D. Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary’s farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep! She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which are sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers, making ice cream, and putting on labels. It was hard not to taste everything!

At lunchtime, I checked on the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and helped a sheep that had fallen over. If they are left for more than 12 hours, they could die, so they need to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, every day of the year! I found it quite lonely. I was surprised how much I missed the children - animals don’t talk back! The worst part of the job is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, so it’s hard to plan any time away. Rosemary will only get about three days off this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is unstable, and I wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has, at the age of 30, become a unique trumpet player in the world today. His recordings are constantly introducing new music, not only concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods but also new pieces. When you meet him, bright-eyed and attractive, he seems even younger than he is, as fresh and open in his manner as the sound of the trumpet. Recently, in one of London's top concert halls, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto, a piece he often plays, while a television feature was made about his work and growth, filmed in both London and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was just eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a trumpet. Instead of a toy, he chose a real instrument after seeking advice. The gift was a success, and the boy never stopped playing. His mother contacted the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, who agreed to give her son lessons. Bo Nilsson was a rising musician who quickly recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, one who was so passionate about the trumpet that he sought out players worldwide and was always looking for new mouthpieces. Hardenberger distinguishes himself from his teacher by saying, 'The trumpet is a simple instrument; you can't create a perfect trumpet. There will always be flaws. Also, no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. For me, it’s about understanding these flaws and building a relationship with them.' From the start, Hardenberger seemed to have a talent for finding the right balance and making that connection. Without boasting, he notes that even as a child, his unique sound was already recognizable, 'the first thing I developed.' Unlike the great British trumpet player John Wallace, who came from a brass band background and later played in orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. As a child, he looked up to the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, another musician who avoided orchestras. He bought all of Andre's records and admired him. His parents supported his desire to practice and encouraged his ambition to pursue a career in trumpet playing. When he was 15, the question arose of where he should study. America, Bo Nilsson's first choice, was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud confirmed Hardenberger's belief against joining an orchestra, saying that 'Playing in an orchestra is like digging in the garden.' He was realistic about his skills, knowing he played better than many his age, but it was only after his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special ability to connect with people. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but advanced to the second. Fortunately, he already knew most pieces for that round too, but in the final, he faced a concerto that had intimidated him before. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance, realizing that even though he 'played poorly,' people still listened. Hardenberger's honest view of his work and career may seem arrogant, but that would be a misunderstanding. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what makes his communication special, saying, 'You risk losing it by trying to explain. The power of music is that it can always move people.'

**Text:**

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insight, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a composed, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her aging father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

**C.** This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears suddenly in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After his recent success, the author has written a sequel filled with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway approaches her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her enjoyable manipulation of both suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary aspects of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

**E.** Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical workday looks like.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and arrive at work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. There have been times when I worked for ten hours straight without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about the next day’s tasks. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is very rewarding, even if there are failures. From 10 am to 1 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. During holidays, I often worry about my patients for the first few days, and I dream about operating at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train to work, and arrive by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work, any issues, or if anyone needs help. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner who oversees everything, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only 10 to 15 percent being design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. I usually have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, often going to the pub, but sometimes I eat sandwiches while working. It feels great when a client appreciates my designs, but it’s disappointing when a project I worked hard on gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be as late as 8:30 pm or later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on two or three mornings a week, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5 am to meet long-haul flights from Heathrow or Gatwick. At around 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. People often ask for my recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which allows me to plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude or unfriendly. However, most are well-behaved, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11 am, we take a break and go to a local café for a big breakfast. Sometimes I wish time would pass more slowly. In summer, I may work until 10 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually set up a consultation in the evening around 7 or 8 pm. We focus on using old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren’t great, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone ringing. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows for creativity."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall that keeps vehicles from driving into a quarry. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. Lunch is typically from 2 pm to 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. The contractors have set meal times, so I use that time to check the site. Since we monitor their work, it can lead to conflicts, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent arises, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Text: Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am to reach the office by 7:30 am. I manage customer development programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, attract new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I oversee advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to address any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes daily, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from session musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for specific artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that people are sharing their hard work, so I try to provide constructive feedback. I can tell if the sound fits our record label. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, choosing songs, a producer, and additional musicians. I also communicate my vision for the album to the rest of the company for marketing and sales. I manage budgets and expenses. I leave work by 7:00 pm at the earliest, and most evenings I attend gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups in one night. After a gig, I might visit an artist in the studio. Most of my social life revolves around my work, and I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client meetings, and wait to see who arrives. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms; there’s nothing better than selling a piece of furniture and knowing it’s going to a good home. We sell antiques priced from £1,000 to £6,000, buying from London auctions, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, and I work closely with our full-time restorer, as well as gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I leave work at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to relax after work.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work a set shift pattern. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift and control one of the four positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, working about an hour and a half at one station, then taking a half-hour break before moving to a different station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic requirements between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. It’s crucial to stay alert in this job, so if I feel unwell, I don’t hesitate to take a sick day. The work can be stressful, and it takes time to unwind after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. The first thing I do is start the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is watching the till and coordinate lunch and break times for staff. In the morning, I assist customers in finding and ordering books. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers’ representatives visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the upcoming months. I need to estimate how many copies of a particular title the shop might sell. When we want to feature a new title, I must ensure it arrives on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Two days a week, I work a late shift, during which I close the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. First, I contact our freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, warning clients about potential issues in those countries. I provide three services: an online executive preview or newsflash, a security forecast that includes a six-month outlook, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with our editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second deadline is 11:00 am, so I need to work quickly to gather stories. I type them up, send them to my editor for review, and make any necessary changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on specific events or to stay updated on the situation. I leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax afterward; I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Text: Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A leader inspires others and helps create change. Leadership is not about being tall or having a high IQ. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is important, and a good leader should communicate clearly and confidently. Dixon says it’s about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, states, "Most people have more potential for leadership than they realize." Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and provided support. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and withheld information, blaming you when things went wrong. The first was a great leader; the second was a poor manager.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes, "A good manager can keep a struggling company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country."

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, improving your leadership skills can be beneficial. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and act on them when you feel inspired.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.
