But it's great fun, and it's all worth it in the end," she says. Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section - but I was the only junior competing. It felt so easy that I waved at my teammates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the run." But she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I let myself stop just once, I would want to do it again." 

Such determination earns admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I've just been testing her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She gave it everything, but while most people stop when they realize they can't go further, she just kept going." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard at it." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with £1,000 off") so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another cost. Her intense training has made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times." 

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events. She has participated in the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's interesting, isn't it?

**Text: The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her passion for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world filled with passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember this: only collect items you truly love. 

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. Attracted by their shapes and colors, these pebbles were among the first objects people gathered for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been collecting for as long as I can remember, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I was sent to a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by others. I was captivated by these items. 

Interestingly, I am not alone in my interest in collecting. One in three adults shares this passion. The reasons behind collecting have become a topic of great interest. Some believe it is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, it is simply something I enjoy.

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like cups made from coconut shells and carved ivory beads. Another notable collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned over 4,000 paintings. However, you don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected various items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, with great determination. 

I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, looking at the remains of my furniture and my collection, unsure which loss hurt more.

I have always been fascinated by how collections change hands. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet adds value to items traded in markets. As certain objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s can now be valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I, unfortunately, threw away both the boxes and the toys.)

**Text: My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I research the exhibition topic and talk to experts to understand the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and pictures to display. I also create interactive displays, workshops, and theatre to help the public understand the exhibition. I work with engineers and electricians to ensure the display is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents need to be created for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, learning the routes. They find the most direct paths, using one-way streets and making the right turns. I help when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a junction. As they prepare for the test, I give them a simple route but tell them they must take a different path because the road is closed. This forces them to think of alternative routes.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. My job involves answering phone inquiries, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. I occasionally go to our main office, but I mostly work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the ocean. I take them out to sea to help them understand marine life better, which often changes their perspectives. I feel lucky because conservation is my passion, but since I work for a charity, I always need to find more funding, which limits what I can achieve.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain a stock of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a dedicated team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there is too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text: No Title**

Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a large house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did so very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to promote their place. One evening, he said, "How about this?" and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not a good experience because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it’s a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, naming the rooms we would stay in. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when few people visit Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles repairs and redecorating. 

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling widely, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel like we were more than just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that the others felt our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was fine. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. 

Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but didn’t play too long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski, often staying on the slopes until 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful," she notes, recalling a fun breakfast experience.

Sarah lives in the chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start at Bananas, then might visit G Jay's and Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturdays because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she says, "especially when you have to cook breakfast with a headache."

On Sundays, she starts work earlier, preparing breakfast for guests leaving by 7 a.m. Once they leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast, stripping beds, and getting everything ready for new guests. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests arriving around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which she finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it's time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but if she's too tired, she prefers to go to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory. She wore overalls and large, unattractive shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. 

Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie loved to watch the workers shape and press each glove using steam-heated brass hands, which she called "pancake hands" because they looked flat and shiny. 

Seymour heard Rita ask, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He was pleased to see her interest in every detail. "They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"Well, you should visit a tannery if you want to write about leather. I can help arrange that for you. They are basic places. The technology has improved, but it’s not that different from what it was hundreds of years ago. It’s tough work. Tanning is said to be one of the oldest industries. They’ve found six-thousand-year-old tanning relics in Turkey, I think. The first clothing was just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject once you get into it. My father is an expert on leather; you should talk to him. If you start a conversation about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers really love their trade. 

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" 

"I can't say I have." 

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 

He laughed; she made him laugh. She was innocent but eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. He remembered how Marie would come home from school, full of what she had learned, everything neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 

"I have an idea. We will take you through the whole process. Come on! We are going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Text: "Is It a Tough Job?"**

Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she must travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss. However, she has one small issue—she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She handles some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her working behind the scenes. She also took a secretarial course in evening classes. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he prefers caddying because golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, which averages between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You're not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge about the game, and try to understand the course," he explains. His skills in accounting were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are valuable to TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the "Food and Drink" section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to taste food at fine restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend, who was an editor of a Saturday Review, offering him a food column. At that time, Martin was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest subway station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mainly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work for them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don't wake up at dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop, which I dislike. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it, there were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that reached down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, all the boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too. 

Still laughing, he watched as they looked down from the roof, nervous and unsure. One by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes until one of them suggested, "Let's go back up to the roof and jump down again." There wasn't much excitement, but they all climbed back up and began to jump off in a determined way until only Michael was left. The others were down below, grinning and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" 

Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly, wondering why the drop had seemed shorter the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and then jump, but when that didn't work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. Soon, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn't move, they began to get up and walk away, still teasing him. 

"Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called out. But he stayed on the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home on time by now. If you won't come home, you might as well stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a bit of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the grinning faces below and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change jobs seek help from a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. Afterward, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggested careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest career advice organizations. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school during science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I reminded myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was difficult to see how the psychometric tests could accurately represent me. They included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, although I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific and technical tests. I’m sure many sick people are relieved I didn’t become a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after losing her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney sought help from Career Analysts. She said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to reflect on my career. I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial situation," she explained. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she chose to use her existing skills and moved into a role that suited her better than insurance. She is now a Public Relations officer. Donna believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, all of whom are satisfied.

Not everyone finds career advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I felt lost. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either meant a significant pay cut or required a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself," she said. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Text: Fun at the Dentist's**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch for patients to sit on while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has tried to create a space where people feel comfortable. He decided not to wear a white coat because many people connect it with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This idea is surprising for many, as most people think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome explains, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past bad experiences." One of his new relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. The headsets are used during the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then the headset switches to a special camera that shows the patient a view of their mouth."

Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit. Another important detail is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people walk in, I want them to feel with all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of treatment is the most crucial aspect. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a bit unusual at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it is not painful at all.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned there is that when you make it easier for the patient, it also makes it easier for you," he explains. He believes that his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a gradual change towards a less formal style in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Text: 'Bitter Water Hits the Big Time'**

Chocolate, which comes from South America, is now a huge global business worth millions. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, which accounts for eight percent of all chocolate sales. Only at Christmas do people buy more chocolate. Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a term that originated from a misspelling in the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in the Aztec language, Nahuatl. In Aztec times, this chocolate drink was flavored with spices and used for ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found it more enjoyable when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but this recipe did not reach the rest of Europe for another hundred years. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk solids, leading to the creation of milk chocolate.

At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. Then, Cadbury introduced the famous Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a strong competitor to rich French brands. Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain seems stable at about four bars per week, prompting manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent marketing strategy is the 'extended line,' where chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something new.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by these farmers.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master of his craft. He still has many interests, including paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells. "Let me know if I am boring you," he says as he shows me his work in his apartment. There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is clearly the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I have grown so fond of them. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so more people could see my art. They even spoke to a gallery owner." This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. Given the high prices of his work—around £2,000 for the ornaments—Cooke seems willing to sacrifice the empty space above his fireplace.

There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else creates work like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

"I wish I had started this earlier," Cooke says, "because I could have made even more wonderful things. Although I still have ideas and do my best now, I am more limited physically than when I began." Nevertheless, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he explains, which has led to boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

Cooke has developed his own method and uses materials he finds. He repurposes cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, uses a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker, and washes the shells with dish soap. "I have an idea of what I want to create, and it just happens," he says about his process. However, the detail, color variations, and symmetry in his work look very intentional.

His search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond his home in Norfolk to beaches in France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines, where he lies on his stomach to find treasures to bring back. He insists he only collects dead shells and defends himself against critics who accuse him of damaging the beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The ones left behind are broken by the sea. I would never collect shells with living creatures inside or dive for them, but once the animals have left, why shouldn’t I collect them?" This argument, based on the limited amount of shells one person can carry, makes a strong case for his actions.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old model who travels to exciting places and appears on magazine covers. When she is not modeling, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

The receptionist at Kira's agency told me, "I'm afraid Kira will be a little late." I thought, "That's fine." I had read some negative things about models, like they can be difficult or vain, and I worried about how late she might be. Would she be an hour late? Three hours? What if she decided to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to talk. 

However, when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and accompanied by her mother. She wore a simple black dress and trainers, not fancy designer clothes. She seemed friendly and down-to-earth. Kira explained that all models under 16 must bring an adult with them to work, and her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was just a regular mom.

Kira seemed a bit surprised by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. "She saw the competition and told me to join," Kira said. "I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When she learned she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen gave Kira the confidence to continue, and she performed well, winning easily. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to balance her two lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some classmates make rude comments about her success, saying she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to handle, as she is not self-important. She said, "They think that because I became a model, I can't stay the same. The only thing that has changed is that I am more confident, but not in a bad way. I can stand up for myself more."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The Select agency can call her at any time for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't promise to join them because I don't know my schedule. I can't make plans, and sometimes they get canceled, but my friends understand. They don't complain that I am always modeling and don't have time for them."

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her, even before finishing her school exams. As I was about to end the interview with this remarkable girl, I asked what she would like to do if she didn't have her beauty. She paused and said, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Text: Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool.

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the most promising land to explore. Since they first cleared the area and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They have dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. After spending their savings on this dream, they need to convince an investor to put £50,000 into the project to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, although we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. "If they are right, it would bring more visitors here," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if these two find gold, I hope millions of people do not come and disturb the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, where they cannot stand up or move, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and she needs to get to the top quickly, she can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey," she says.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When she is not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers,'" she explains. This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This smoke flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

"The only time I was scared was during my first dive with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible—we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD. When I finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

Text: 'I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I said as I stepped onto home ground. I repeated this the following year and the next. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Ordinary beds feel different once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, rocked into a deep sleep. Carrying all your belongings in a rucksack leads to a simple way of traveling and encourages wastefulness, like burning socks that have become too dirty and getting rid of books after reading them. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be set aside along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to feel this freedom is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I initially thought this train ticket was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of continuous travel was too tempting, as there was always one more country to visit, just a little further away. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like most other Inter-Railers. In planning our own schedule, we focused only on the most accessible sights. This was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that, in many places, all I wanted to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and enjoy ourselves. In this, we were like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was once just a name. It feels like the city you arrive in never existed until the train pulls into the station, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you experience it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip may not reveal new things about the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail offers the best chance to appreciate this, though it didn't happen for us right away.'

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you may be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in unsuitable clothes. Although airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is a common issue that regular travelers will eventually face. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially when your journey involves changing planes.

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also extended to allow for luggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to delayed flights, which can disrupt the baggage system. Human error or accidents, such as a torn destination label, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 

For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom transferred between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The risk of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for luggage going missing when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America.

To reduce the chance of losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all legs of your journey. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**Text: The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing shade to the shallow water. The main colors are soft greens, browns, and various yellows from the sunlight, as gentle as the sound of water in the breeze. The bird moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, so striking that you can almost feel its presence. It disappears in an instant, but the image stays with you, its impact greater than its size.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep feelings for this little bird are shown by his uncertainty about what exactly attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body turned blue like the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this. Despite the many shades of blue in their feathers, kingfishers do not have blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, reflecting blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about them. The combination of their colors and the fact that kingfishers, although shy, can be observed easily from a hidden spot creates a perfect opportunity for a lifelong interest. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite place. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a major part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream full of kingfishers, but school limited his time with the birds. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Yet, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then worked as an assistant to the editor, and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I’m drawn to the simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks of the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever show.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis speaks with five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna and ended up filling in for an absent assistant. She was later invited to help with another opera the following season. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I have always felt confident standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, supported by the British Arts Council. Since that first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several more projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
The hardest part of being a conductor is figuring out how to get the right opportunities, says Andrew Constantine, 31. He won a major competition in 1991 after unsuccessful attempts in two others. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened any sooner, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many performance opportunities and a chance to work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, Constantine struggles with being known only for the competition: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are now inviting me back. If that doesn't happen, my career could suffer."

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial center until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size—previously, I had only learned from much larger conductors, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many disagreements, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
"Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me," says Roger Vignoles, 48. This career choice is not so unusual; he began as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well, understood how I wanted it to sound, and did my best to achieve that. Thankfully, people respect my skills as a musician. I benefit from every experience I've had, both in musical style and performance. Now, I will accept any opportunity to discover what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor during one of his productions and informed his agent about Wayne Marshall. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best result. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need guidance from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express what I want. If people see you're anxious, it only gets worse. I have never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island would be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young children, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are more thrilling rides, like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere, and the scenery was not very impressive. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could see easily! The older children liked the ferris wheel and enjoyed driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still much to explore. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. For younger children, Toy Land is a lot of fun. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they found out they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not too boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member kindly went with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am quite timid, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it a little boring, but they were the right age and enjoyed it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we certainly felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out in the park, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Text: Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. "My customers are friends," says Christine Hogan, who runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were young, and I wanted a job I could do from home. I had worked with computers before marriage, so my husband suggested I start a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. I was careful and always informed the bank manager if I might overspend. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evenings if I choose. The business has stayed small, and we rarely deliver work; customers from the area usually pick it up."

B. "I enjoy being independent," says Maggy Sasanow, who designs greeting cards from home. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where such jobs were not available. So, I decided to start my own business and now create a range of 50 greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. My business relies entirely on word of mouth; I don’t advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I miss exchanging ideas with others, but overall, the benefits outweigh the drawbacks."

C. "It has been hard at times," says Delia Turner, who runs a curtain-making business that has had ups and downs. "I started my business eight years ago when this type of work was growing. In two years, my earnings increased from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to manage six full-time curtain-makers, but I had to let them go due to the economic decline, which was painful because finding other jobs in this area is difficult. Now, I am back to making curtains at home with my husband’s help and using women who work from their homes. I must be ready to lower my prices when needed and explore new opportunities."

D. Tessa Strickland manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons: it was cheaper than London, and I love the countryside. I enjoy being able to work when I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at unusual hours. The downside is that I need discipline to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. I had all my professional experience in London, so I felt very alone at first."

E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home. I am very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with high-quality flour and eggs. Soon, I received requests from friends and family, and I started sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where everything is made; we have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don’t bake anymore, as I manage the business side. My biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, which has been tough because we didn’t have a lot of money to start with."

**Text: Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. Matthew Rye reports.

Many families have musicians, but it is rare to find one with writers, performers, and an instrument maker. When John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they were surprised by the high prices. John says, "We looked at different shops, and it was clear it would be very expensive. So, I thought about making one myself. I found out that the Welsh School of Instrument Making was nearby, and I took evening classes for about three years."

Paul, now 28, adds, "After trying to make violins and violas a few times, Dad made his first cello. It turned out really well. He made me another one later, which I used until a few months ago." John has now retired from teaching to work full-time as a craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a great achievement for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul remembers, "I started with the piano as soon as I could reach the keys. But soon, I wanted to play the cello. My parents wanted me to play the violin because Dad played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. I tried the violin for about six weeks but didn't enjoy it. I was inspired by the cellist in Dad's group, who I thought was really cool. He offered to give me lessons, and that started my journey."

Huw says, "My parents were supportive but not pushy. I think I would not have done well if they had forced me. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul's success, I found it motivating." Now 22, Huw is starting to make a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

John's cello has helped Paul achieve great things. With it, Paul won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20 years old, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which he has on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul says, "Dad hasn't said anything about my new cello, but he did try it and admitted it sounds nice! The only thing my dad's cello might gain over time is the ability to project sound in large concert halls. It will get richer with age, just like my Rugeri, which is already 304 years old."

Soon, Paul will perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto, which is part of a new series called Masterworks. He says, "The history of the piece doesn't change how I play it. I will always do it my way." However, Paul won't be able to watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will need to be organized and energetic to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Text: Looking After the Countryside**

**The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with one of the wardens employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it manages.

Common sense is essential for a National Trust Warden, according to Gareth Roberts. "You also need to be good at dealing with people because you are always interacting with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies." Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the position of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. "It helps that I still farm with my parents, so I can relate to farmers and understand their issues. They can't fool me!" he says. His farming background also means he can handle the physical demands of the job, such as building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls.

Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. "When I was younger," he remembers, "I used to pick flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and find old birds' nests. Recently, I thought about where I would find those flowers and nests now. It has become clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault; they were just following government instructions."

Gareth notes that when he started, farmers and conservationists were often in conflict, each wanting things done their way. Now, they are communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. "We are at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," says Gareth.

Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to ensure tasks are completed efficiently and with minimal fuss. What I enjoy most is seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork."

Gareth is passionate about his job and, despite always being on duty, he enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. Most of them, anyway. "I dislike the attitude of some visitors," he admits. "They come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to those people can be frustrating!" But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. 

So, if you have plenty of that and like the idea of working outdoors, you might consider applying to become a warden like Gareth. However, don't expect a position to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula for quite some time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, typical for the weeks before the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket car park. 

"Don't you get strange looks?" I asked her. She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it." 

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to be as fit as possible." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the biggest yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People expect us to start the tournament with a strong game." 

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra notes that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only have one chance, and you must be ready to make the most of it." 

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train hard not to win," Kendra says. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We are all friendlier after the game." 

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. "As captain, I believe it is important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team." 

Kendra adds, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may very well have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents may not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help academically gifted children, musically talented students often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who are musically gifted, or whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools offer a supportive environment for children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend a significant part of their day—between one third and one half—on music-related activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which allows them to spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. The cost is a significant issue, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 a year for boarders. Each school tries to help families with scholarships and financial aid for exceptionally talented children. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

Separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met. For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before pursuing a specialist education.

Students who excel academically may thrive in a less specialized setting, such as a school with a strong music program, or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, along with orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, and the large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west show a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures. This is largely thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant."

Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. However, she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of the flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they each change into different shapes. They open up and look amazing. When you first put them in a vase, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants: "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers. I thought they looked like the fake ones sold in some flower shops - to me, the only real flowers were wild ones. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliff tops."

Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards the garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but despite needing to paint, she knows that to stay connected with her subjects, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys being on the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it makes her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful," she notes, while acknowledging that some weeks are more challenging.

Sarah lives in the chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start their night at a place called Bananas, then might go to G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturday nights because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she says, "especially when I have to cook breakfast early."

On Sundays, breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah quickly cleans the chalet, clearing breakfast and changing the beds. If she hasn't done the shopping for the week on Saturday, she does it on Sunday. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which she finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she may chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear for my day at Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around when I could be quietly cuddling an animal. Some members of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job is not very pressurized. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked one of the elephants, I thought Mandie would probably be packing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening program Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice.
