I enjoyed being in the fresh air because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My idea of gardening did not include hard physical work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective, so I don’t plan to quit my other job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out tablets. I thought I would faint doing some tasks, but I surprised myself by managing well. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very friendly compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital was not pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drink a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, it is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I ever saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we had to take the Desert Express. The schedule was unreliable; we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days to leave if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, there was a rush of people climbing into and onto the carriages—some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
I think most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are young, but that’s not true for me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains and hardly traveled on them. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had carefully maintained. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Want to get published? If you’re unsure where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Who should I send it to?" One important thing to know is that you need to research your markets and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your words into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the "writing game." No matter what type of writing you do, you should learn about the markets you want to reach. There are several ways to do this, but the best way is to read as much relevant material as you can. Visit your local library and explore nearby bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. This knowledge needs to be updated regularly since new publications are always appearing—editors change jobs, and magazines change focus. Publishers are always looking for new talent, so as writers, we must provide what they want. 

At first, you might be unsure about what to write. For example, if you think you want to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories, a limited market these days, and get recent copies of those magazines. Then, learn about the types of stories they are buying and who their readers are. These readers will have different expectations, and the editor wants to meet those needs. Writers often send me their stories asking, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it’s unlikely that the work is ready for publication. I try to give honest feedback while remaining positive. The issue is that many new writers are too eager to submit their work, often before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This almost never happens. When you read about someone’s "success," you usually find that they have been in publishing or journalism for years before achieving that success.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more while you wait for a response; write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your fluency and confidence. Don’t discard any of your work—improve it instead. I also recommend not sharing your work with others, especially in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby. If there isn’t one, consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

**Text:**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I had expected. The usual clean and bright feeling of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers one by one. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn’t mind talking to her. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, northbound, yes," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" 

"No, New York, but I'll be..." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. "Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said, "Wilmington," he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn’t; I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed now. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five—older than me. A schoolteacher type. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Then could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist (even though I didn’t have a watch). I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They were announcing my train now. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets on leashes. 

Next, I heard the man talking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn’t know what to do." The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where he was going with this. 

"So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would get someone to bring her passport." I thought this was a strange story. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? "Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. He believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant. When John learned about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in very poor condition, but it was just what he needed. Starting this business reminded him of his childhood. He remembered how his mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad being left alone. Because of this, he wanted to make time for family. His wife took care of the children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This focus on family helped their children, Gary and Joe, become very confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and accidentally knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he had plenty of money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John enjoyed seeing Gary contribute. Although Gary was not very good at school, he excelled in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would pursue a career in catering because of his talent.

When Gary needed to do work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant. Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary’s cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one goal, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told him, "If you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by age 30. After that, it’s too late." 

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students struggled, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his work in just an hour. He even helped his classmates. No one can believe how successful Gary’s TV cooking show has become, and John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that hard work is necessary to achieve anything because nothing is given for free. Gary recognized the opportunity he had and took full advantage of it. John reflects that as children grow, parents can only hope they remember some of the advice given. He feels that Gary must have listened at times, given the things he says and does.

**Text:**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you could afford was very difficult. The best way to find one was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often helped. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts to tell you about available rooms. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For her, Dublin felt like a big unknown. She felt nervous when she took the train to work there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave. Who would stay in a small town? That’s all she had heard for years. Her friends wanted to escape, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates had moved to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them settle in. But none of Jo's classmates were going to Dublin. She was going alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel run by nuns, believing it was safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were often cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying a whole week in a hostel. But Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her as she answered an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive! 

There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about needing a "Third Girl" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal—an ordinary red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, clearly a failed applicant, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she told Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." 

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up the stairs. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can’t stand that kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked. 

"Do? She didn’t have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, was a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one. "I’m Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat." 

Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one had "Nessa," one had "Pauline," and the last one had "Other" written on it. "We’ll put your name on one if you come to stay," she said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are among the smartest animals, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by television shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by law and cared for in marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen only in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once often seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, including the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, such as skin injuries.

The complex behavior of dolphins makes it hard to understand why their numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is greatly reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also endangers porpoises and dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died after being caught in these nets.

Pollution in the sea can also harm dolphins. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies because they dissolve in fat. Female dolphins produce milk that contains these harmful substances, which can poison their young. There is already one recorded case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**Text: GETTING FIT**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to. 

Exercise improves your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also helps prevent muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. Additionally, exercise can improve specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits before, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you’re not convinced yet, just think about it—exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to overdo it, as training too hard can cause injuries. If you’re unsure about what exercises are right for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. If you have poor posture, it can make you look and feel less energetic and can lead to health issues. To improve your posture, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head up towards the sky. This can help you lift your chest for better breathing and make your body look slimmer.

Stretching your muscles is also important. It improves flexibility and helps you move easily, which can prevent injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, and it should be done slowly and carefully.

The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to many unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their partnership has produced some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a well-received film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time tracking the shy jackal.

Traveling filmmakers have been exploring the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. "We do have occasional arguments, but we usually resolve them quickly," he said about working with Amanda. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they view the animals similarly. "When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But this time we have a more fixed camp, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be stressful," Newman said. 

It can be a tough life, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman recalled filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often wander off. When she returned, she would greet all the pride members, and eventually, she included their vehicle in her greetings. 

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they began filming Arctic foxes together. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a strong working relationship from the beginning," Newman said, "because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe evoking an emotional response is more powerful than just appealing to logic."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to achieve maximum fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and provide more support. People expect us to start the tournament with a strong game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra notes that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only get one chance, and you must be ready to take advantage of it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train hard to lose," Kendra says. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We are all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the rest of the team."

Kendra says, "From the very beginning, my netball career has been carefully planned." She decided some time ago that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she will probably have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters are with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

"Inside," she says, "the space is so small that I can reach out and touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, which means we can't stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting samples of rock and water, and then three hours to return to the surface."

"If something goes wrong and you need to get to the top quickly, you can hit a panic button. The outside drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that is released, and it rises quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

"I didn't know how I would react the first time I climbed into the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing how I would react in such a small space." 

Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site that was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys blowing out black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When she is not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes—water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I was scared was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible—we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Research shows that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believes being on time is very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, explains that interviewees who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. While many believe that what is inside matters most, it is important to present yourself well in an interview.

Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview, leading to an immediate job offer. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. Once her boss sensed her enthusiasm, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can greatly affect the success of an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can provide information about the company's activities. Mentioning an area of interest during the interview can create a positive impression and show your interest in the company. Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She states, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer exciting; it became a grind. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly made redundant. I didn’t receive a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed for me: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist felt like the right decision. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a leap into the unknown. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky; many of them visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
After working for five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. "My job as a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even more hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. Since it’s a fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for the product. If I do a poor job, I am the one who faces the consequences. Of course, you care when working for a company, but when your name is on the promotional material, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in financial markets since I was 22, setting up deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left voluntarily and traveled for a year. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I was offered part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That is the best part."

**Text: 'Dedicated to Their Sports'**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training can be expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It’s enjoyable there with great facilities and nightlife. However, I must be disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to decline. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics—that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I do enjoy sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it is worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice getaway. The sacrifices are worthwhile because winning that championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I guess I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
Being on a boat with five guys is always fun. We have a traditional way of celebrating our wins. Some say we act a bit childish when we celebrate, but we don’t seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to return home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can’t focus on the sport all the time; it’s not healthy. I am known in the sailing world, but I can count how many times I’ve been recognized in public on one hand. I wouldn’t want to be a celebrity. I do receive many nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I make sure to reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the support of the crowd. At my last tournament, things got a bit hectic with fans crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping. However, it has its challenges. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I received too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that’s part of why we broke up. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport; you must be serious and professional. I’m focused on my game now and plan to enjoy other aspects of life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It’s a tough situation."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when compared to attractive advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It’s important for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy things. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels unhappy about how she handles their shopping requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in their responses to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we load our trolley with cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract enough extra customers to make up for it.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created after extensive research into what customers want and nearly two years of work converting four large 18th-century houses. This approach allowed for the installation of advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to track guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special treatment for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests. At the Merrion, a high-tech system allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a significant part of the hotel's clientele, making up to 65% of its business. To cater to their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by laying extra cables and renting televisions, allowing for easy upgrades.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished bedrooms that are inviting. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The food at the Merrion is of high quality, as Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the hotel. This partnership benefits both the chef and the hotel, as he has designed a modern kitchen and improved parking facilities. The hotel gains a successful dining option without financial risks. With its technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**Text: Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I think excitement gives me energy. I need to be challenged and learn new things. Right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing, which is very energizing. If I'm bored, I feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, boosts my energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not a chore for me. When I get enough sleep, I feel great. I know exercise helps, but sometimes it's hard to find the energy to do it. I attend a yoga class weekly and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don't eat healthily for energy; I think it's my natural enthusiasm and positivity. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people energizes me. I enjoy taking photos and writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and being positive. I love working with kids; they are full of energy and resilience. Energy is like a natural spark that comes from connecting with others. Smiling at people can create a wonderful feeling. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking and drinking, but I don't have a strict exercise routine. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is turning a wasteland into a garden. I once transformed a concrete area into a beautiful garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also gives me energy. I enjoy sneaking into nature, and if caught, I playfully say I didn't know it was private."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe it's important to have an interest in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don't want to do drains my energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I found them exhausting. You have limited energy, so focus on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron was introduced to Scandinavia around 200 AD. Among the upper classes in Scandinavia, skating was considered an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant and formal, but at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style that made skating very popular. Today, skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are very important, and speed comes with practice. The way you position your body affects your balance. Keeping your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed helps you stay centered, with your body leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is crucial in skating, more than in many other sports. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outward. As you push forward with your back foot, make a small movement with the other foot. If you can maintain this for a while, you can gradually increase the length of your movements as you gain experience.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed, which helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up. Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can practice different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle.

With proper instruction available at most ice rinks, you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle. If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, it is important to follow a regular exercise program. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits your heart and lungs and strengthens your body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates an excellent program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Bills**

If there's one thing that can make you cry with joy, it's seeing a talented child receive a medal. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.

A. Annika Reeder, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She hopes to become a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time, and when I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off. But usually, I just keep going – you can’t take too many days off, or you get stiff."

B. Annika's mother said, "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen some parents try to push their kids, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy, and you have to want to do it yourself. People often tell me that we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a very shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence from her success."

C. Sarah Stokes started show-jumping at age ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents love show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it – I love show-jumping; it’s exciting and fun. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I am determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I’m not doing it for them. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. Sarah's mother said, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age one, I knew she had found her passion. When she was five, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we have to travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living quarters of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is completely happy on a horse and knows what she is doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is an amazing feeling."

E. Jane McShane, 10, is Britain’s Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should; I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about getting a big head; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."

F. Jane's mother said, "Jane played her first game when she was five. My father suggested we see if she liked it. He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age six, she was beating adults. Of course, I’m happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to hold her back because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how we were as cavemen. We are starting to lose the effects of many years of poor diet, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are beginning to reach our true potential. We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived on Earth 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

Over the years, we have mostly eaten soups, porridges, and breads, which have left us underfed. In a study in Ohio, scientists found that when they started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be a blessing, turned out to be a health problem, according to some experts. 

Despite this, agriculture spread because one piece of farmed land could support many more people than hunting could. The issue of poor nutrition has only recently been addressed, even in wealthier countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Although people are getting taller, the standard bed length has stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing companies are constantly adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. Some scientists, like Robert Fogel, believe we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. 

However, there is a twist. While individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we may shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman explored this question. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of television, but many of us find them mysterious. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are often seen as the least important type of audience. Some people in television even look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home don’t understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through hours of boredom just to watch something they can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be on television for a moment. I didn’t believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for a chance to appear on TV. Another reason people attend is to see behind the scenes. However, the most common reason I heard was simply, "A friend gave me a ticket."

Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you respond accordingly. This may be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We believe a show should be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live television. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing live actors; from my seat, I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters. For most audience members, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Text: Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I do not like completely wild landscapes. The human touch is important to me. This is also true when I travel abroad. I am drawn to charming villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England, and on Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a break from school. I enjoyed exploring the bare hilltops, the sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. In a way, that was my first attempt at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by volunteers. I always travel first class because it does not cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery is not amazing. The train travels across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. However, there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our small train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers peek into people's lives, seeing them make tea, wash dishes, or set up a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people's homes. It is the everyday nature of the landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This makes me look more closely, searching for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and filled with rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to admire the power of the sea. The coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys, full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns some property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there and not many visitors either. It is a hidden, empty, and remote area, and I enjoy the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and since then, I have visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is the place of my dreams. It is a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are 'animal people' who love all kinds of creatures. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to say she had found a beautiful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked excitedly. I replied, "Yes, but only for one night." We had prepared a special tank for such visitors, just long enough to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly put a pot on to boil when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The crisis involved Domino the cat and Bianca, the white mouse I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around the room with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the chaos of waving arms and furniture.

I jumped into the mess and tripped over something, landing on the floor. As I thought about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It had escaped and was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat were jumping around in a loud, chaotic scene. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over.

I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet, and surprisingly unharmed mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, that same mouse was caught by Domino three more times during its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged by my success with the cat, I examined the snake for any weak spots, but it had none. In the end, I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without a flute. Gradually, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked suspicious. I slowly slid my hands under the snake and carefully stood up, walking to the end of the garden. There, I pointed the snake towards a tree, giving it the chance to live happily in the garden.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to strike, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter. We stood together in the fading light: four young children, their mother, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

I had the children gather at the snake's tail and gently encourage it to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished from our sight, three-year-old Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Send me a message! In our fast world of phones, faxes, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is a unique experience that no other form of communication can replace. There is the thrill of its arrival, the joy of seeing who it is from, and the pleasure of reading its contents. Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. Sometimes my father would write, and I always enjoyed his long, funny letters. Most letters from home shared everyday events about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most. I also received letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I often met people who had to work or study far away, and we kept in touch through letters. Instead of hurting our relationships, letter writing seemed to strengthen them. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than in conversation. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to receive a whole year’s worth of news! It’s even more exciting when it comes in an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from a friend I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There’s also a lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn’t started talking in a restaurant on the way home from vacation, if my husband hadn’t taken her photo, and if I hadn’t asked for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a wonderful friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French (she doesn’t speak English); we have visited her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a friendship could last so long. The local newspaper even thought it was newsworthy enough to feature on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.'

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain, which was once a place for prayer, has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include images of cows, fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being harmed by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and damages the artwork. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer," he explains. "The drawings are naturally polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look newer."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He warns that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says, "Henry de Lumley's plan is very strict, and while it may be effective, it will likely upset local residents." He adds that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't perfect. Our department believes the best solution is to let people visit the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I would prefer that everyone could see it, but the main issue is money. We do not have enough funds to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee, as there seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—tourists can now avoid a long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't happen because there is no money," she says. "That is not acceptable. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for future generations."

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and when I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry they are missing out on learning to make their own choices. I feel stuck."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, and arguments about the dangers of sugar are not convincing when compared to attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It’s good for parents and children to talk about food, because if children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes, "The goal of advertising is to persuade viewers to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels uneasy about how she handles their shopping requests: "My son notices ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in their responses to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, while we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers, making up for any loss in sales.

**Text: Climbing Walls**

In the past, climbers went to mountains to climb. Now, you can find challenging climbing experiences both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches in excitement as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but both events share one important feature: The Wall. The ability to have these events is due to new and rapidly advancing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs with good climbing angles. In winter, they either braved the cold, went for walks, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became essential for top climbers to stay fit. Since cliffs were often unusable, they began using brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them strengthen their fingers and avoid boredom from not climbing.

Soon, many sports centers started building climbing walls specifically for training, using bricks with special edges. One of the first climbing walls was created by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He came up with the idea of embedding natural rock in concrete blocks to create climbing walls. Throughout the 1970s, many similar walls were built in sports halls, but they had clear design issues. These walls could only be vertical, while outdoor cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Additionally, once built, the walls could not be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a change. French manufacturers also started to create panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for making overhanging walls without significant construction, but steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system of interchangeable holds provided climbers with endless new challenges.

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will likely mention that it is a risky career. Acting is indeed risky because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were friends may think you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. Ultimately, it is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own path and dreams. There are no easy ways to succeed in acting—there are no exams to pass, and completing training does not guarantee a job. Success depends on both luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes wealth.

Many people ask what talent is. I believe talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. The desire to act can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform.

When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often do not have a clear answer. They understand some things about their skills and techniques, but they do not take their success for granted. They know they are only as good as their last job, and fame can be fleeting. Disappointment is a major challenge for actors. One month you might be unemployed, doing other jobs, and the next month you could be auditioning for a role. Even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of success. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected, and this possibility exists from the moment you start auditioning. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the role. In many ways, your success depends on your own commitment; if you do not care enough, others may not care about you either.'

**Food for All**

We are excited to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and author, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, showing her love for exciting food and her understanding of what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. The book that made her famous is *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, which is now a key reference for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of interesting recipes. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc took just 15 years to go from an amateur chef to the owner of the most famous French restaurant in Britain. To go along with his first TV series, *Blanc Mange*, he has released a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients behave in specific ways. He believes that good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 amazing recipes that illustrate his points. It is a practical guide that explains why some dishes can fail and introduces basic food chemistry to help clarify these ideas. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking to entertain, and this book shows that he is very skilled at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve excellence. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have published a new book, *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are all classics, they still feel fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also adapted its recipes to reduce rich, creamy sauces and lower calories. The book starts with basic kitchen procedures and includes sections on Appetisers and Starters, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have chosen a recipe they are known for and shared their secrets with readers.

D. Fast food? No way! Many believe that good food requires a long time in the kitchen. However, Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees.
