His new book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes that quick meals are what people want when they come home tired and hungry. He has always thought it is possible to make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered, and he has written two successful books to prove it. In this new book, you will find many tempting recipes, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel shares over 200 recipes from around the world in his cheerful and enjoyable style. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you doubt that fast food can be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on Earth 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when they started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a blessing, some anthropologists see it as a health disaster. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of land could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are poorly nourished, but this issue is being addressed in wealthier countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have not changed since 1860, remaining at 190 cm. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we may shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer exciting; it became a grind. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly made redundant. I didn’t receive a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a leap into the unknown. We moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky; many of them visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
After five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even longer hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. Since it’s a fashion business, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for the product. If I do a poor job, I am the one who faces the consequences. Of course, I cared when I worked for a company, but when my name is on the promotional material, I care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in financial markets since I was 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left voluntarily and traveled for a year. During that time, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That is the best part."

**Text: A Winning Game**

Two brothers have discovered that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are at their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, enjoying their childhood memories. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they believe is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played the game and, as Dave says, "had the best time ever." Eventually, they moved to New Mexico, but they kept playing with Grandpa's pichenotte board, made from old wooden crates. Visitors were often intrigued because the game was unknown in the southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave noticed how worn the pichenotte board had become and decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon they sat down, and before long, they couldn't get up from the table!" When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched it. He found that the roots were likely in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This game evolved into 'squails,' played in British pubs, and British immigrants brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec.

Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks.' They flick the pucks across a wheel-like board using their middle or index finger. Getting a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points, respectively. Eight small posts act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity increased. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, and the brothers decided to start a pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and began making boards. They have produced over 450 boards so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12 kg and is 1 cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable, as they need to withstand a lot of use." They are available for $595 each on the brothers' website.

Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage to create pichenotte stars. However, the day may come when the brothers' garage will hold a luxury Mercedes instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this was an empty, overgrown piece of land. For a long time, it was seen as useless. However, through careful planning and hard work by one man, with the support of his wife, this area has been transformed into the beautiful place you see today. 

During the construction of the village, many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of manual labor was also involved. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rockeries. 

In building the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These plants were carefully chosen to survive in the salty air near the sea and to withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were imported from as far away as Canada and New Zealand. 

The entire village was designed by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by hand over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from various materials—stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics—to endure all types of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how different materials would last over time, but he quickly became skilled himself. 

You will notice that a consistent scale has been used, and great attention has been given to even the smallest details of the models. This was achieved through patience and the development of unique building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality craftsmanship and upkeep. The methods used to create these realistic models have been adopted in other model villages across England and have even been included in some college courses on modeling. 

All the buildings in the village represent traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. As you walk around the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models; even a small mistake can lead to hours of repair work for us. You may take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Pressing these will make the models move. At the end of your visit, we welcome any feedback you may have. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations. We are constantly updating the models and need to know which ones need attention.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Please tell your friends about us!

Text: 'Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and violate the editors' code of practice. While pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people contact the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to address these issues. Rarely are these pictures in the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel—a place where, according to the code of practice, 'there is a reasonable expectation of privacy'—she had a valid reason to complain, but she did not take action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. It should also look into the shocking story recently published about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead on this and other disgraceful attacks? This seems like a good idea. It would likely result in many decisions against newspapers. These would be reported by their competitors and shown on TV and radio. The public would not be sympathetic, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as they would no longer be able to afford to hide behind trees waiting to take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it could technically do, there would be several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an inquiry? Should it contact the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still refused to act, should it proceed anyway? Additionally, celebrities and royals might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and then be upset if it wasn't. Most importantly, the role is too large. How could the PCC realistically monitor all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the issue of embarrassment to consider. No matter how much someone's privacy has been violated, would they really want the added embarrassment of an investigation? I believe most people just want to move on with their lives. Of course, some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might exist that they have kept from the press, and they know that this could also become public if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become an enemy. One British comedian faced problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he when he and his family were photographed without permission during a family holiday. His reason was fear that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', claiming they thought it was just a joke, and that, as a film star who makes comedies, he would have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find an easy solution to this serious problem.'

Text: 

Many college graduates receive advice when starting their first job. This article focuses on moving to a second job. We are not discussing those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, nor those who leave a job they dislike within a few weeks. Instead, we will talk about those of you who are ready to take a significant step in your career. You have gained some experience and skills and have a clearer idea of your career goals. 

What kind of job should you seek? It largely depends on your long-term goals. You need to consider whether you want to specialize in a certain area, aim for higher responsibilities, or explore a broader field. Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years, as it will be closely examined when you apply for your next position. This job should demonstrate that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and increase your responsibilities. 

If you feel the urge to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can take temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again soon. 

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. It was a great first job because they were very supportive. She learned about office work and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no opportunity for advancement. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. 

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. "In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really evolved," she says. "From the start, my boss was eager to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I began, but my responsibilities have changed. I have moved from mainly typing and answering calls to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also manage various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes me in all her work and also assigns me specific projects and events to organize."

**Text: 'What is the Secret of Confident People?'**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but many will say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I was nervous but surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I felt very anxious, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school changed my life and helped me in many ways.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became a bit too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that true confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel unconfident, so I often talk to myself to calm those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as confident, but I often feel scared inside. I had to learn to appear confident because it is very important in my job in TV. Interviewing people has shown me that many of us feel nervous in important situations, but we feel better when we talk to friendly people. My mother once told me, “Who’s looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about themselves.” I remember this advice often. I also believe that facing your fears helps you gain confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed, and that made me feel braver.

**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work, but I have built this confidence over time. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone will like you. You must accept yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers many training courses, which have helped my self-esteem. They also encourage us to set realistic goals. It is helpful to see that you are achieving something instead of trying to do everything at once and ending up with nothing.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings, afraid to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I first worked in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with fear. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.” I also found it helpful to write down a few notes to refer to, like a comfort blanket! I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is reminding yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Text: Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's traditional - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking out at Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a line of tense competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 

"Flying kites isn't too hard," said Adnan, "but making them requires real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he asked me to return the next day to start rebuilding his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. 

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, a sign caught my attention. It pointed up a footpath into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before starting, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. 

The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a stunning view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. 

No one stays a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their curiosity was friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

**Text: 'What kind of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, we all go shopping. There are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked several people...**

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
"I'm a shopping addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We're an addicted couple!"

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
"I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter shopping, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't often spend money on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and usually tell my husband I spent less than I really did. The real price always seems shocking."

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
"I only shop for essentials. I dislike shopping and only go when I really need to. When I do, I know exactly what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather be doing something else."

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and try to get in and out quickly. However, I do have some items in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes!"

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
"I really dislike shopping. I find it hard to find clothes I like or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I don't have to shop for clothes often because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and get it done quickly!"

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
"I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my girlfriends, and we often end up spending money. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it."

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
"I'm a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and don't go overboard. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I often end up feeling worse because I've spent too much!"

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'm a careful shopper. I usually have a good idea of what I want and don't rush into buying things. I check other shops to find better deals, which takes me a long time!"

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
"I'm an unwilling shopper. Working in the city center has made shopping less appealing to me. When I have to shop, I go reluctantly and don't bother trying things on because it's too much trouble. The clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!'**

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University offers degrees like any other university, but you can study without leaving your job. It allows you to explore many interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the excitement of learning new things. You will meet a variety of people. Your degree may also lead to new job opportunities. Instead of attending lectures, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. You can choose to attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams to take, just like at any university. If you want to learn more, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets can be collected from the desk at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and asked various questions about them. The quiz sheets will be available during normal gallery hours from March 25 to April 9.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery now features a beautiful still life by the Dutch 18th-century painter Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) of flowers and fruit is created in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for a painting like this to have two dates because the artist waited for specific flowers to bloom in their seasons. This artwork was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is now displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the Late 18th Century" opened in the Sunley Room on March 15. Recently, the Gallery has acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain during this time: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until May 31.

**Lecture News**  
The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On April 5, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work, while on April 12, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On April 19 and 26, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is pleased to announce that an improved and expanded service is now available in the Gallery restaurant. With new kitchens, the restaurant offers a wide selection of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery take place every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and showcase the entire range of the Gallery's collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Text:**

The Outdoor Centre Fees are for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Fees should be paid at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organization that aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation facilities for everyone. Group visitors should inform the centre in advance of their planned visit.

**Windsurfing - One-day Course**  
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Boards with small sails are provided for beginners. Course fee: £32.50 (this includes all equipment).

**One-day Adventure Course**  
This is a chance you have been waiting for. Come and try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have previous experience. All you need is an interest in the activities. Course fee: £22.50.

**Play Park**  
The Play Park is suitable for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best in the country. It features sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

**Group Day and Residential Courses**  
We also offer day and weekend courses for groups. We regularly host schools, colleges, and youth groups. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**  
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are fully trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children participate in activities that are suitable for their age and physical abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting, a hobby that is both interesting and enjoyable. Every year, more individuals start their own stamp collections and find a passion that can last a lifetime. 

Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from family, and letters from pen pals. Once you begin collecting seriously, you may want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club, which helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection. 

You can receive these stamps in three ways: 
1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack filled with interesting facts.
3. If you prefer, we can send you individual stamps for you to organize in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too! A two-year membership costs just £5. If a group joins together, you can even get a discount. This is great value for money! When you join, the Club will send you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also receive a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to grow your collection and useful addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will get a copy of the Club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes. It also gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members from around the world. 

Why not start an adventure that will bring you years of joy? You will spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unique ones that are waiting to be found. 

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and experience the fun of stamp collecting! To join, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent to you within 28 days of receiving your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are similar to a gram or a kilometer. The key difference is that you can trade money for goods or services. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. 

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money as we understand it today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, traded the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of currency to facilitate trade. Eventually, different currencies began to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky winners will receive a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges, including novelist Mary Littlejohn, television reporter Michael Brown, and Keep Writing's editor Susan Hitchins, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything, but here are some tips to help you: 

1. Write about what you know. This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most stories were about love, family, and friendship problems. However, you should make ordinary situations interesting so that people want to read them. 

2. Get your facts right. It is important to describe places or explain things accurately. Only write about topics you are sure about. 

3. Hold the reader's attention. Start with an interesting beginning and end with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a story. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the ending. 

4. Think about the characters. Use descriptive words to make the people in your story feel real to the reader. 

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and printed on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, as per a recent rule change. The story must not have been published in any form, such as on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that his daughter received the best education possible. This was rare, as most women at that time had limited chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work. During this time, many rulers feared science, and those involved in it were at risk. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is twelve kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is near the A1 main road. There is also a two-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to the peaceful Yarwell, the current western end of the line.  
**Fares:** Adult £10.00, Child £5.00, Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. There are thousands of hectares of public parkland with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from many parts of Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these engines all year round, whether or not the Nene Valley Railway is running. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. A good example is the film "Octopussy" from the James Bond series. Come and see where it was filmed.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups to visit and for teachers to set projects. The work can be done while students are here or in the classroom. A special educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. A month’s notice is required for booking. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. For more information, call 01780 784444.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular choice for special family events or company visits. It can provide a unique setting for an interesting afternoon or evening. Special programs can be arranged to include buffet, bar, entertainment, and discos. For more information, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Text: Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. They are the only flowering plants that can survive in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. 

Grass grows back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. Once they have eaten all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing fresh food.

Text: 'Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and recently won the title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she has drawn clothes and created designs. She never told her parents, who run a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After finishing university, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to industry events but couldn't buy the designer clothes she liked. So, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. She then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. The clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned. This motivated her to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she gained public recognition by winning this award. She feels her business has grown a lot, and she knows she is very fortunate. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.'

**Sunningdale Hotel**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service to guests from all over the world, welcoming people of all ages and nationalities. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have visited Sunningdale. The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center. It is about a 20-minute bus ride from the center, and buses to many other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue "Express" sign, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are located at the end of the corridors. The hotel features a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests to use. Parking spaces are available in the hotel driveway. Daily newspapers are provided for free, and stamps can be purchased at the office.

Guests who stay for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance, and they need to give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are as follows: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. For those studying or working late during the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or by calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires of any kind (for cooking or heating) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise level low, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests are advised to take a taxi to the hotel if they arrive by train, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

**Text: Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in film history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and found it hard to make friends, even though he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter while also taking drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he had become so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after a long trip of over 500 kilometers. Both the driver and Bo were hungry at the end of the day. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. As it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner had also been looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

**Text: The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses the Australian continent, from the warm northern coast through vast desert to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," which is somewhat unfortunate because it is known for being late. The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide began in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but serious flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished a few months before my journey. The railway was built for speeds of up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train—there are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to Australia's populated south via Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent. It is rare for a transcontinental railway to be completed, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. 

As I waited to board the Ghan, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. The Australian pensioners, who made up most of my fellow travelers, were especially eager to get on. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train did not meet all the promises of the advertisements, it had taken me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Text: Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is located in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high, making it one of the longest climbs in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are necessary because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some members of our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothing. 

Although the weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, we still felt nervous when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path quickly became steep, and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they would start again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we were not lucky that day, as mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as challenging as going up. You need to read a map carefully because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I could only say I truly enjoyed the experience once I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

**Text: Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, similar to our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The school took many months to build, and we watched the process. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, even though it meant some beautiful open space was lost. The noise from the construction machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. At times, we thought the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five large classrooms, much bigger than those in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and spacious changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the warmth comes from everyone inside—the children, teachers, and computers. The building is designed to keep the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof because it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for the lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so large that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures that we plan to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being completed. For example, we are currently preparing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never thought that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place was not luxurious, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn were with Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we were not sure how. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock-climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.'

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do; I am 72 years old, far from home, and quite worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained my situation. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what had happened, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had found it and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, and amazingly, everything inside was untouched. I want to thank everyone who helped me that day and express my appreciation for their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Text: Sharks**

Sharks are some of the most frightening animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they can see very well and can feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. 

Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they hardly ever sleep. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who need to handle sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting creatures.
