Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. On my first day of ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came over to ask me questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and then they switched to English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very friendly, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers well.

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late one night to talk to her because I was feeling lonely. The classes in Russia are much harder than those at my ballet school in England, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This gives me confidence to meet the school’s high standards.

In the evenings, I like to watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I have settled in, I feel at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the locals said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular summer destination to see the land of the midnight sun, but in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, it was decided that the dark and cold winter could be seen as a positive thing. In the winter of 1990, French artist Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors to the area. One night, a group of foreign guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous worldwide.

As soon as winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is completed in December, and each week after that, a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outdoors using natural winter materials, the finishing date depends on the weather, so sometimes plans change.

In spring, as the weather warms up, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5°C to -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothing such as warm overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks, and to choose shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items and any equipment you need when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Text: Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, including a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had announced it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening.

A police officer who was called to the shop said: "The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The shop quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could enter, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space for them inside. Another problem was that there was a long line of cars trying to get to the parking lot. I couldn't believe that many people decided to leave their cars in the middle of the road and walk the last few meters to the shop. This blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: "I waited in line for three hours, and I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. So I'll come back when they reopen, but I'm not willing to wait in line again."

**Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in Britain.

**Society Magazines**

We produce several excellent magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine features short stories by some of Britain's best writers and offers many chances for new writers to publish their work. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, includes interviews with writers and has information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing community. To see articles from recent issues, follow the links on this website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We run the National Short Story Competition, the largest competition of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and short stories on any topic are accepted. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members pay £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best entries will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**

For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and helping them gain confidence in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place with freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is the perfect spot to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members receive discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world, and anyone aged eighteen or older is welcome to join. If you are interested in joining The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

**Text: Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on just one breath of air. In 2003, she made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean and return to the surface without assistance. Although she had dived deeper a year earlier using a balloon to help her return, this time she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man. A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. 

Some people argue that free-diving is too dangerous, especially after reports of serious accidents involving other divers. However, Tanya believes that safety is the most important factor, followed by proper training. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya maintains a consistent training schedule. Two-thirds of her training is done on land at the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to prevent knee injuries. Instead, she prefers fast walking to build her fitness.

When preparing for practice dives, Tanya usually travels away from home. She aims to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, ensuring she has a rest day between each diving day to avoid fatigue, which could affect her performance. When not training for an event, she often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects and films.

Having spent her childhood on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, Tanya enjoyed swimming and exploring rock pools to observe sea life. She feels that her life now reflects her childhood dreams. Being well-known in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she discusses environmental issues. Looking ahead, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. Since she only started free-diving at twenty-five, she is eager to emphasize that she does not plan to retire from the sport for many years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few restrictions. If you can draw something, you can animate it for the cinema. The introduction of new ideas and advanced computer technology has made cartoons exciting again for audiences of all ages. By the late 1970s, the film industry believed that cartoons were only for children. However, shortly after, a few directors came up with original ideas. They showed that it was possible to create films that both adults and children could enjoy together. Nevertheless, not every cartoon film was a success. For instance, The Black Cauldron did not do well, mainly because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this experience, and film companies started to earn significant profits again.

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson discusses her first role on television. "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. I took a year off to travel before starting university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to adapt the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to audition for the role. She was surprised at first but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the role. The outdoor filming began a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. Once I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was exciting. It was an incredible experience, and I feel so lucky. After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I’m not from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I have auditioned for other TV roles but haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I didn’t know what to do next. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I’m going to Greece for the summer with friends."

**Text: No Title**

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is shared in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. 

This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can make a positive impact. In both business and life, I want to feel happy, have a sense of family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. 

Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' or to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private showers and toilets. On board, you will find air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** Depart in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Your guide will meet you upon arrival and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After a morning of sightseeing in Oporto, you will return to the ship and depart for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drink.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego, where you will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. You will then return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return journey to Tua will be by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** There will be a trip to Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then heading down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with plenty of time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweetener because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey highly and even used it as payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed all over the world. Research indicates that honey can help reduce tiredness and enhance athletic performance. Additionally, honey is not only food; it can soothe sore throats and is found in many skin and hair-care products.

**Text: Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had become one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a significant center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It continued to grow for 300 years, becoming wealthy and famous for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and its role as a modern commercial center (it is the largest center for insurance services outside London), Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', whose colors are green and yellow, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's recent developments is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich dealt with a large hole in the city as builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a city center park on the roof of the Mall, complete with water features and many trees. The local community is happy that the old open market remains in the city center, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that happens every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the center of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected to participate at its current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The pilots communicate with each other using radios, and they all light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This event is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great chance to take amazing photographs. To see these "glows," you should arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 AM, as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, with some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, as well as popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Children will enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies that offer rides. Another option is to ride the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a view of the festival from above. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates ideal conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are important. Bring a flashlight for nighttime events and, of course, your camera. If you use film instead of digital photography, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and nighttime photos.

**The Eden Project**

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist attractions. The large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many products we use every day come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone in the near future.

Text: 'No Title Some people have expressed dissatisfaction with this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I do not understand why. After all, 500 pages of original writing of this quality for £6.99 is quite impressive. Most of the book consists of fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable works by well-known authors like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, lesser-known writers often focus on food in their pieces. I recommend caution with Jane Harris's Those Nails; it should not be read right after meals due to some very unpleasant scenes! The collection features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. It also includes excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Additionally, there is a small amount of non-fiction, including a humorous article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and a remarkable piece by Ursula Owen about her own life. This is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will bring.'

**Text:**

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's when you are discovering the world." Margaret, who lives in London, usually teaches children who are three or four years old, but she has made exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old friends.

Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts one hour, every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her each week. Parents must also attend the classes because it is important for them to be involved in the lessons.

From the beginning, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and their ability to read music. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists, and she often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD: Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. 

From the first song, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is shifting away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance track and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will likely surprise many fans. Either could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford has a chance to showcase his talent, hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded these songs before experiencing throat issues, which led to the band having to cancel their upcoming tour. (Anyone who has bought tickets need not worry, as all concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.)

On this CD, Moonshine demonstrates their ability to create great music in various styles, from the familiar slow songs to upbeat tracks that will keep you dancing. However, I felt that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not quite as strong. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

**Text: San Francisco**

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, San Francisco Bay, a beautiful natural harbor, was discovered by land instead of by sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest individuals were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill known as Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous sites like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the former prison.

**Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS'**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and interesting account of daily life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys discusses significant events of the time, such as diseases, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his own flaws—like often falling asleep in church or admiring pretty girls. He describes his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they reconciled, as well as his concerns about her health. In addition to reading, he enjoyed music, theatre, card games, and lively parties with good food. Pepys was a busy man with many important roles; he served as a Member of Parliament and was President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not focus on shoes being comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also common, depending on current trends. It was only about one hundred and fifty years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, while some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to produce many more affordable shoes for a larger number of customers.

**Text:**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women get involved in running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident enough to start. I decided to create a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with how some race organizers think. They often say there are not enough women in the sport, but they also use this as a reason not to provide separate changing rooms.

I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn't think about having fun, chatting, and enjoying beautiful places while running, like by a river. At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about diet and staying fit from other runners. I wanted to support women's running, and it has been a joy to see their progress—almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people moved there hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. 

During the summer, supplies could be brought to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to reach them. To solve this, a winter trail was created in 1910 for dog teams pulling sleds. They delivered mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska, stopping at 'roadhouses' where drivers could find a warm bed and food for themselves and their dogs. 

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced boats and dog teams as the main transport. However, in 1925, the dogs had one last important mission when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in the cold. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away at that time. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead. 

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. Twenty teams completed the trip in just six days. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be a great help. The last part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further, preventing the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Text: Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite this, around 6,000 tourists visit each year to experience one of Europe’s most unique hotels. In this hotel, guests eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there. The bar is also made of ice, so it is not advisable to place hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are kept at about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to keep warm in the cold. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing can also be provided. The hotel lasts for only six months because it melts in the summer, and it is rebuilt each winter. Constructing the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Text: Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized she was very fast. 

"He talked to me about athletics. I didn’t understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help their family. They agreed to let him take her away to train. 

In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is stunning, and it is made even more impressive by the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and a glass floor, allowing visitors to see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of visitors have experienced it. To protect the glass, you must wear special shoe covers. Walking on the Skywalk gives you the feeling of floating high in the air like a bird.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch nearly the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest but are also found a few hundred miles from the center in southern regions. Although the Rockies are not as tall as the Alps, they are still incredibly beautiful. There are many roads that cross the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. 

You can start your journey from Vancouver, which is one of Canada's most beautiful cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from downtown. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver each day for the cross-country railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey is still an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you will see some of the most stunning views at night.

Text: 'ZOOS People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years, starting with a large zoo in China called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals were trained to perform for visitors, but this practice has stopped. Now, the main purpose of zoos is to allow people to see animals in their natural behavior. Most cities today have a zoo or wildlife park. However, opinions about zoos vary. Supporters believe that zoos help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close, which would not be possible without them. On the other hand, some people oppose zoos because they think it is wrong to confine animals in cages. They argue that poorly managed zoos can have dirty conditions and provide unsuitable food for the animals.'

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we held a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band had their own costumes, from black school uniforms like my band wore to brightly-colored T-shirts. We didn’t look much like professional adult bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of our playing was impressive, especially considering how young we are. Players from each band even created new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band performed!  

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets accepted—only about half, in fact. However, anyone who is eager to play attends jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country—I’ve been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher believes it’s because pop music isn’t challenging enough for serious musicians like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music while also feeling connected to its history, as you perform on stage like great jazz artists before you. My school is very fortunate to have excellent teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn’t make progress in our music!

**Text: Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, rain is rare, and when it does fall, the city's water pipes often cannot handle the sudden floods, causing the streets to become like rivers. Many winters have been dry recently, so when it rains, the local people are very happy. 

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain; instead, they are fed by a system of underground channels built in the 11th century that bring water from the mountains all year. Places that are mostly dry but receive water this way are called oases. 

Further south of Marrakesh is Skoura, where every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels to grow food. The snow-covered Atlas Mountains in winter create a beautiful backdrop.

**Text: Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis, 13, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always dreamed of being a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in the circus. They both found jobs with a well-known circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and return home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. 

"I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." 

"People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the start, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." 

And what about the future? "It was a hard decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. These are sent to major national and local newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet others and participate in projects, and we plan to open more centers soon. Since our agency began in 1994, originally called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined. Sophie is one of them. She says: "I first learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was impressed by the opportunities they had. Age didn’t matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I started attending the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and was a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought I could. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older who train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who accompany them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, please call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. These flights take you over Antarctica and back. The exact dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to a different date if needed.

**Questions**

Here are answers to common questions about our flights.

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history, and they answer your questions. There is a camera next to the pilot that shows a view from the cockpit throughout the flight.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will be asked to move to the seat indicated on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While flying over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting sights so that everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain checks the satellite images of the clouds and chooses the direction with the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Text: Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog may appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to cause you to lose control. A car coming towards you might slide unexpectedly across the road.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to be aware of your surroundings. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London to study law but chose to attend art school instead. He found the traditional drawing classes challenging, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government funded his art studies, and he became interested in early Italian artists, which is reflected in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This inspired him to layer colors from light to dark, although he admits he is never certain of the outcome. He says, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top."

Like many talented artists, Aitchison makes it seem easy. "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just pay attention to what colors are next to each other." Unlike some artists, he does not create sketches before starting a painting, as he believes that doing so might make him lose interest in the final piece. Instead, Aitchison often changes his paintings multiple times before they are complete. This is why he prefers to work with models who do not ask to see their portraits while he is painting. "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since moving to London, he has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He claims he is not interested in following any tradition and simply paints in his own way. Nevertheless, his work continues to inspire young British painters.

**Text: 'Rock Band'**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against it because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing video games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for several hours each week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical talent; after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager. They do play regularly in local clubs for young people. 

Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but this hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is clear: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Text: Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. It offers students valuable experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to study for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from all over the world, study in the morning. In the afternoon, they participate in useful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body, coming from various social backgrounds and countries. Since many students cannot afford the fees of £20,000 for two years, financial aid is available. About a quarter of the students are British, and many can only attend because they receive government support.

"I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you may not like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued much less with my sister."

In summary, Atlantic College provides an excellent education through effective methods.

Text: 'Being an Older Student

At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job did not challenge me. I became increasingly unhappy with the thought of being stuck in that job. I envied the students at the local university, who seemed happy, carefree, and full of hope, and I wanted to be part of that experience.

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I am grateful for this chance to study because I understand that a qualification is necessary for a rewarding job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. I also enjoy the typical student benefits, like long holidays and discounts for theatre and cinema.

I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in my life has been a wise decision.'

**Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. At the age of fifteen, he started working as a mechanic, and in 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and created two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong yet light steel, he made affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he produced the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 

Dear Sir,

I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? How long is each course, and when does the next one start?

Yours,  
Maria Gonzalez

Dear Ms. Gonzalez,

Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. It is a 6-week course and costs £150. If you prefer to start in June, we have another 10-week course for £200. I hope this information is helpful.

Yours,  
David May

**Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS'**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very difficult. "You must carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often ask her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!

Text: 'Dear Mike, I am sorry you could not come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and stayed in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party; the best I have ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

**Text: CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they must fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds cannot survive if they stay there. Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds will not know how to migrate in the autumn." 

Bill owned a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese followed him. When autumn arrived and the weather turned cold, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way.

After reaching Virginia, Bill left the geese there and returned home. This spring, he waited for the birds to come back, but they did not arrive. So, Bill flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not locate them. When he returned home, he was surprised to find the geese waiting for him. They had managed to find their way home without his help!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, Esther decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly earned back her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents were not supportive of her jam-making. They wanted her to study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther ignored their advice and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked.

After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She made various types of food to sell to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire some employees to help her.

Text:

Would you like to go to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema?

Love,

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them cool. 

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters from the wool and tried to sell them at local markets. Unfortunately, it was summer and too hot for people to buy sweaters. Instead, she made socks, which everyone loved because they were affordable, durable, and easy to clean. This is how Jenny's business began. 

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers, so she had to send the wool to a factory where machines now produce all the socks. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different types of socks for walkers, athletes, and skiers. Jenny is busiest during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. On the walls of her office, there are many letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

Text:

Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,  

I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made many new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher, John, who helps me when I make mistakes. I want to visit London next weekend because I am returning to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.  

Best wishes,  
Maria'

**Text: 'BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON'**

Most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that the number of house burglaries has increased by over 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave their homes and forget to lock a door or a window. He noted that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home then. However, winter afternoons are the best time for burglars since it is dark and they can hide easily. Many houses are often empty during this time because people are still at work.

Inspector Saunders suggested that it is wise to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when going on holiday. This can help deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to keep an eye on each other's houses when someone is away. They should call the police if they notice anything suspicious. "We will also provide advice on how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This kind of help is free."

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, 

Thank you for the two nights I spent in your lovely home. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They are nice photos, aren't they? I hope you enjoy them. I really love my new camera. Next week, I will visit my sister in New York. I will take many photos there as well. I haven't seen my sister in a long time. Thanks again. 

Love, 
Roy'

**The History of Farming**

Before farming began, people searched forests for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started to grow their own food. These individuals were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, leading to the growth of larger villages. Some villagers could then focus on other jobs, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming could be challenging during bad weather, which sometimes left people without enough food. Today, farmers can produce more food, which can travel thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.

**Working for an Airline**

Nicola Peet left school at eighteen, attended college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she began working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years later, she became a manager. Here is what she shared about her job:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I train flight attendants and assist them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight schedules on my computer, and then I talk with some of the flight attendants. Occasionally, I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are performing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I enjoy office work as well. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat something and then go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Text: 'Dear Maria, I am happy to be back home, but I often think about the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I felt sad when I left England because my visit was too brief. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in another city. I have started taking English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How are you? Are you still searching for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'The Weather People study the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various professions. For instance, the weather significantly affects farmers. In the past, farmers spent much time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Today, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even access weather information on their mobile phones. Many people still hold onto traditional beliefs about the weather. For example, they say that a red sky in the evening means it will be sunny the next day. Some also believe that if cows lie down in the fields, it will soon rain.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who has difficulties with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing sounds than by reading. His brother wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to develop the game, and now it is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many awards for their game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in purchasing it.'

**Text: 'HOW DOES THE IRISH POP GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE?**

Getting enough sleep is very important. When I can return to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, I find it hard to sleep at night after a concert because my mind is full of music. 

Staying active is also important. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours at the sports center every day, five days a week. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups each day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthily and drink a lot of water because it is good for your health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that.

People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I like to listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. Since the doctor advised me to eat better, I no longer feel tired. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day, but I still enjoy burgers occasionally!

**Text: 'Bollywood'**

'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, which is more than the USA, making it the largest film industry in the world. Most Indians prefer watching films to any other leisure activity, with ten million people visiting cinemas every day. Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are key elements in every film. These films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost around $2 million to produce, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, often considered India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films over a career that has lasted almost 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson was born in the United States but has written many travel books about England. He lived there with his wife and four children for 20 years, but for the last three years, they have lived in the United States. Their children are now learning about life in the United States. Bryson believes they will be happier because they have experienced two countries. He enjoys Britain and wants to return, but his daughter, Felicity, is starting college soon, so it will be another four years before they go back. He recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to discuss his new book. Most writers do not enjoy this; they dislike traveling around the country to promote their books. However, Bryson does not mind it. He enjoys visiting new places and meeting many people. This experience is very different from his life in the United States when he is writing. In England, people drove him in large cars, and he stayed in nice hotels. It was good because he did not have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to him, and it was fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes arrived in England over 50 years ago, while the Giant Schnauzer is a more recent addition. The name "Giant" is fitting because these dogs stand between 65 and 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular grooming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, whereas the Giant Schnauzer is typically black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where they assist farmers with sheep and are also employed by the police due to their intelligence. Schnauzers make excellent family pets; they are friendly and great with young children.

**The Ruwenzori Mountains**

Mary Daniels is a student from England. This year, she had a fascinating summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest connecting two large towns. 

"It was very challenging because there was no drinking water and no shops to buy food," Mary said. "It was also very cold and rainy in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world." 

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. Although it was hard work, she believes it was the best experience of her life. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I am a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework. Hester'

**New Books This Month**

**The Long Night**  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for many years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, where she works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha must drive all night to take her to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey.

**Hard Work**  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. *Hard Work* is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they do not earn much money. One day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop.

**Hospital or Cinema?**  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young woman from Brazil who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who invites her to the USA to become a film star. What will Tina decide to do?

Text: 'The History of Horse Racing

Horse racing has been an important sport since ancient times. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in both Greek and Roman cultures. Modern horse racing started in the 12th century when Arab horses were brought to Europe. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses, but by the early 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and included several horses competing against each other. Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball, and it is also very popular in many other parts of the world.'

Text: 'World traveler Nick Barlow enjoys his job. He is a British actor who travels the world making TV shows. "People are friendly to me wherever I go, and when I return home, I remember all the amazing experiences I had in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still a few trips he wants to take. "I would love to visit South America and return to Australia one day," he adds. On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed to make the show. Nick doesn't pack many personal items, just a few shirts and pants, but he always makes sure to include some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, is fine with him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she enjoys listening to his travel stories. However, sometimes there are challenges. While in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick learned that his wife was sick in the hospital. "I felt awful because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so relieved when I found out she was better."

**Text: Parrots**

You may have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in forests or zoos. Parrots are found in countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many different types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold food. The largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very loud, but they are intelligent and can easily learn to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about many of the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he chose not to buy many clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also collected many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much harder to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has made the right choice.'

**Text: John Pickering**

In a small town in central England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers in a park. Last week, he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television because he is currently the top singer in Japan. A few months ago, John visited Japan to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on his radio show. Many young people called the radio station to ask for his songs to be played again. 

John, who goes by the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, plans to continue working in the park in England. He is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know that he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change how we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"
