**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. In nearly every town, there are clubs and classes for this activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to meet new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few elderly men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was growing larger. The city was very dirty, and many people lived in poverty. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, causing people to stay at home as much as possible. 

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of individuals to stop the thieves. They were similar to police officers and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown so large that it needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was established with 3,000 officers. Most of the men patrolled on foot, while a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are well paid, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Would you like to join a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The cost of the trip is £25. It gets very cold at night, so please bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to come, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people travel to Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with actors and artists from around the world. They come to Edinburgh for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are full of music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting in the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists visit the Festival to watch new films and plays and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be challenging, so consider booking your hotel now!'

**ICE-FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim beneath the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. 

"You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top," he says. "Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. You put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!"

Text: 

From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I'm having a tough week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he got a summer job. We can't go camping together now. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's Museum is a well-known attraction for tourists in London. Visitors can see wax figures of famous individuals. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him in this work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, and only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from modern ones. Over time, as bicycles became less expensive, more people started to buy them. Many began using bicycles to commute to work and for leisure activities. 

Today, cars are used more than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to ride bicycles to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went directly to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers gave a new brush full of paint to each elephant and took the old one away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We fed the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they no longer work there, but the smartest of these animals live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats dislike water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These lions often work together to hunt for food. They typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats require good eyesight to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I am sorry, but I cannot attend your class anymore because I must return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be much work in the kitchen. I regret leaving the English class. You are a wonderful teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you again. Best wishes, Soraya.'

Text: 

14 Sheffield Road  
Rotherham  
20th May 2002  

Dear Mary,  

I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and let me know when you are free and where we can meet. I hope to see you then.  

Yours,  
Joan  

20 Didsbury Drive  
London NW1  
22nd May 2002  

Dear Joan,  

Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a nice Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please try to be on time!  

Yours,  
Mary

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I am happy because last month I started a new job in the city center. I work at a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I begin work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up very early! I enjoy this job because I meet people from many different countries. I like sharing information about our city with them. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, weighing over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometres an hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are the size of chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has won many competitions in this sport. We spoke to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked her why she chose to start snowboarding. She said, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months." 

When we asked her about practice, she replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains; it’s so beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best part for me." 

We also asked her what is important for beginners. She explained, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It’s also essential to have the right clothing to stay dry because, at first, you will fall a lot!"'

Text: 

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,  

I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I prefer a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could I please have a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel. Is there a parking area available? I expect to arrive around 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would appreciate a meal upon my arrival. Thank you for your assistance.  

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are several routes to the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to complete and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the summit succeed. This is often due to sudden changes in the weather. At the start, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, climbers encounter ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Text: Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were few otters in Great Britain because the rivers were very polluted, which caused many fish and insects to die, leaving otters without food. However, today there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.

Text: 'Dear Deshini, 

I am happy that you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but I now live in England. Please write to me and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you could send me? I am sending you some photos of my family. I will send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon. 

Tom'

Text: 

'17 Green Street  
Camden  
London  
29th August 2002  

Dear John,  

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a great teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then return to Greece. I really like London. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. It was very sunny, and we had a wonderful time. Tonight, I will watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write again from Greece.  

Best wishes,  
Kostas'

Text: 

'Dear David, 

Next month, I will visit your country with two friends. We are unsure where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would prefer to stay in the center. Can you help us? 

Carlos 

Dear Carlos, 

Hotels in the center are costly, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria, and she said you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! That will be fine with you, right? 

David'

**Text: Buildings**

People have always created buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We also use buildings like museums to display beautiful items. Many people work together on a building project. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to share their ideas. Engineers ensure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. 

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from all sides, not just the top. Another well-known roof is on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.

Text: 'Indre, I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The issue is that I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills is a large figure of a man. This figure is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. It is not clear when the Cerne Giant was created, but many believe it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always smiled and laughed, which made people in her city love her. Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with a very good time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he cannot keep up. 

Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes a break from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Text: Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and a year later, he began playing the piano. He gave his first concert at six years old. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he hopes to write his own music.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. "My ten grandchildren don’t live nearby, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad." This way, Bill has learned what young children enjoy reading. 

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His favorite book is his fifth one: *The Sheepdog*, which is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest technology to make it seem like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn’t change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often nicer than personal photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it showed a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards included images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important people. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

Text: 'Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaurs died about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied greatly in appearance, with over 5,000 different species. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever existed. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and primarily ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was smaller but much stronger, equipped with sharp teeth for eating meat and long back legs that allowed it to run quickly.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can kill a person. Bears are skilled at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears: The largest is the white polar bear, which can be nearly three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish-brown. The black and white panda bear, which comes from China, is loved by many. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually live in slow-moving water but can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat a variety of things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they also eat larger animals or even people. There are more than ten species of crocodile, and they all have very sharp teeth. Although they often lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Crocodiles are typically about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. They have long lifespans; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Airplanes changed significantly over the next thirty years. Then, in the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, making the trip from London to New York just four hours long. Today, millions of people fly on airplanes, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

**The Globe Theatre**

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round, had no roof, and people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors ate, talked to friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place by the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I am enjoying my holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple! Australia is very beautiful. We do not want to go home! I will see you at the end of September. Sue'
